content.raw:
Per f2f, having `//include/uri` resolve to a directory \(via a `model://` or `file://`\) is the use with Gazebo for models. \(Not necessarily the case for  meshes, etc.\)

This should be addressed in a proposal, as it’s not ambiguous.
content.html:
Per f2f, having //include/uri resolve to a directory (via a model:// or file://) is the use with Gazebo for models. (Not necessarily the case for meshes, etc.)

This should be addressed in a proposal, as it’s not ambiguous.

pull_request.title: Legacy/current behavior of model level composition

pullrequest.title: Legacy/current behavior of model level composition

content.raw:
Now that I’ve complained about this here, I’ve reviewed our Drake code, and see that we use the version which doesn’t supply the extension in the URI:  
[https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/blob/d8b52a67cff0b2a823db46effc631a6e0051bcc2/multibody/parsing/test/sdf\_parser\_test/include\_models.sdf](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/blob/d8b52a67cff0b2a823db46effc631a6e0051bcc2/multibody/parsing/test/sdf_parser_test/include_models.sdf)

That being said, we haven’t really used `<include/>` \(I believe partially because of the issues we’ve mentioned here?\).

I would like to find out more about the rationale of the model manifest; I understand it’s for abstraction, but I’m still not a fan of having to go through that mechanism.

EDIT: Yeah, reading this: [http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=model\_structure&cat=build\_robot#ModelConfig](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=model_structure&cat=build_robot#ModelConfig)

I’m fine with the abstraction, but would still be nice to not require – if it’s still ambiguous in the spec.

EDIT 2: To clarify, yeah, wasn’t expecting that the model database would be changed!
content.html:
Now that I’ve complained about this here, I’ve reviewed our Drake code, and see that we use the version which doesn’t supply the extension in the URI:
https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/blob/d8b52a67cff0b2a823db46effc631a6e0051bcc2/multibody/parsing/test/sdf_parser_test/include_models.sdf

That being said, we haven’t really used <include/> (I believe partially because of the issues we’ve mentioned here?).

I would like to find out more about the rationale of the model manifest; I understand it’s for abstraction, but I’m still not a fan of having to go through that mechanism.

EDIT: Yeah, reading this: http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=model_structure&cat=build_robot#ModelConfig

I’m fine with the abstraction, but would still be nice to not require – if it’s still ambiguous in the spec.

EDIT 2: To clarify, yeah, wasn’t expecting that the model database would be changed!

ok, I think I was getting mixed up between what code has been released and what we have in the frame semantics WIP PR. you are right that released code doesn't check those things for validity

in the WIP, `ign sdf --check` does check, and `Model::Load` does a lot of checking while building the kinematic, frame-attached, and pose-relative-to graphs, but it doesn't pass on those errors at the moment

Is there a way to make that more explicit, in that model manifests aren’t required by libsdformat  or the spec?

Is there a way to make that more explicit, in that model manifests aren’t required by libsdformat or the spec?

content.raw: I don't believe those check for the validity of the links referenced by a joint's `<parent>` and `<child>` elements. I originally meant that `libsdformat` doesn't check the validity of links specifically for nested models. Looking at the code, I don't think there is any validation even for non-nested models. I tested with `ign sdf -k` and I don't get any errors. I also tested with `ign gazebo`, but the error is generated by `ign-physics`, not `libsdformat`.
content.html: I don't believe those check for the validity of the links referenced by a joint's <parent> and <child> elements. I originally meant that libsdformat doesn't check the validity of links specifically for nested models. Looking at the code, I don't think there is any validation even for non-nested models. I tested with ign sdf -k and I don't get any errors. I also tested with ign gazebo, but the error is generated by ign-physics, not libsdformat.

pull_request.title: Legacy/current behavior of model level composition

pullrequest.title: Legacy/current behavior of model level composition

content.raw:
ok this is weird, but libsdformat does extra weird stuff to nested models if they are included instead of directly embedded (see [parser.cc's sdf::addNestedModel](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/c760f10bca16306d4fc3f0308a19f95f504c3412/src/parser.cc?at=default#lines-1066:1142))

it looks like it moves link and joint elements directly into the parent model after prefixing their names with `modelName::` and altering their poses. it also modifies the joint axis assuming `use_parent_model_frame=1`!

I think this was a hack to support nested models in sdf 1.4 before it was officially supported in sdf 1.5. This seems really bad!
content.html:
ok this is weird, but libsdformat does extra weird stuff to nested models if they are included instead of directly embedded (see parser.cc's sdf::addNestedModel)

it looks like it moves link and joint elements directly into the parent model after prefixing their names with modelName:: and altering their poses. it also modifies the joint axis assuming use_parent_model_frame=1!

I think this was a hack to support nested models in sdf 1.4 before it was officially supported in sdf 1.5. This seems really bad!

pull_request.title: Legacy/current behavior of model level composition

pullrequest.title: Legacy/current behavior of model level composition

content.raw:
perhaps we could be more explicit and say which API's in libsdformat don't check that links are valid

I think the `sdf::read*` API's won't check that (ie. `sdf::readFile`, `sdf::readString`, `sdf::readDoc`, `readXml`)
content.html:
perhaps we could be more explicit and say which API's in libsdformat don't check that links are valid

I think the sdf::read* API's won't check that (ie. sdf::readFile, sdf::readString, sdf::readDoc, readXml)

pull_request.title: Legacy/current behavior of model level composition

pullrequest.title: Legacy/current behavior of model level composition

content.raw: The uri, name, pose, and static elements are the only ones defined inside the `<include>` tag in [sdf/1.6/model.sdf](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/c760f10bca16306d4fc3f0308a19f95f504c3412/sdf/1.6/model.sdf?at=default#lines-28:45) and [sdf/1.6/world.sdf](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/c760f10bca16306d4fc3f0308a19f95f504c3412/sdf/1.6/world.sdf?at=default#lines-24:39), but there is also some special handling for `plugin` elements in [parser.cc's sdf::readXml](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/c760f10bca16306d4fc3f0308a19f95f504c3412/src/parser.cc?at=default#lines-883:899). Perhaps we should add that to the specification?
content.html: The uri, name, pose, and static elements are the only ones defined inside the <include> tag in sdf/1.6/model.sdf and sdf/1.6/world.sdf, but there is also some special handling for plugin elements in parser.cc's sdf::readXml. Perhaps we should add that to the specification?

pull_request.title: Legacy/current behavior of model level composition

pullrequest.title: Legacy/current behavior of model level composition

content.raw: This is how gazebo classic does it, but only because [gazebo::common::SystemPaths::UpdateModelPaths](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/13b71990d5449de589e4dcaa83dbc711394650ed/gazebo/common/SystemPaths.cc#lines-208) calls [sdf::addURIPath("model://", path)](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/c760f10bca16306d4fc3f0308a19f95f504c3412/include/sdf/SDFImpl.hh?at=default#lines-67:72) for each path listed in the `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` environment variable. We should probably describe how to use the libsdformat API, rather than just describe how osrf/gazebo works.
content.html: This is how gazebo classic does it, but only because gazebo::common::SystemPaths::UpdateModelPaths calls sdf::addURIPath("model://", path) for each path listed in the GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH environment variable. We should probably describe how to use the libsdformat API, rather than just describe how osrf/gazebo works.

content.raw: I realized that the use of the `<include>` tag in the [Creating Worlds](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=spec_world&cat=specification&) tutorial was incorrect in that it directly used `.sdf` files. I have updated it to use directories in this PR ([preview](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=spec_world&cat=specification&branch=model_comp_legacy)).
content.html: I realized that the use of the <include> tag in the Creating Worlds tutorial was incorrect in that it directly used .sdf files. I have updated it to use directories in this PR (preview).
